facts: The word "puzzle" comes from a 1500s English verb meaning to confuse or bewilder someone.
Word-search puzzles train your brain to spot patterns by scanning letters in many directions.
Crossword puzzles became widely popular after a puzzle was printed in a New York newspaper in 1913.
A palindrome is a word or phrase that reads the same forward and backward, like "racecar."
A pangram is a sentence that uses every letter of the alphabet at least once, like "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog."
Sudoku is a logic puzzle that uses numbers, but you do not need math to solve it because it is all about placement rules.
Jigsaw puzzles are often said to have been invented in the 1760s when a map was pasted on wood and cut into pieces for learning.
